bibl.note: This is a letter from Robert Anderson to William Bell, referring to their legal transactions. It is dated July 24, 1847. Anderson writes that he received one slave, John, in good health. He agrees to keep him because of his bad eye sight. He also agrees to allow Bell to return another slave named Jack, as long as he is still in good health.

div1.p: , this day I hove Recd my in fine plight. By William D. Beatman my Jack. you ask to have the Refusal of him Next spring so you shall have the Refusal of him provided both my Jack lives and in good helth

Negro Man John hath come Holm in good Helth his Eyes Excped. he always was Near sighed. tax ⁁ but Never Lost time on that account. he Now say in warm weather water ⁁ he work hard and swets he gits Blind, and Can not git his Wood being his situation to be so, if you are Willing I am Willig to Keep him at holm ad Credit you with the balance of his time
